issue.title: Renegotiation with custom BIO buffer with less than 33 bytes space fails
issue.body:
OpenSSL Version: OpenSSL 1.0.2j
OS: macOS Sierra 10.12.3

When a renegotiation is initiated a 33 byte payload is generated by OpenSSL. If the BIO doesn't have enough space to hold 33 bytes then OpenSSL will not attempt to re-write the remaining bytes after space becomes available in the BIO. I am developing a custom BIO implementation and documentation is sparse so it is very possible I'm using the OpenSSL APIs incorrectly.

Steps to Reproduce (Use a BIO which has 32 bytes free space)
1. Complete a handshake
2. Server initiates a renegotiation (calls `SSL_renegotiate`, returns `1`)
3. Server calls `SSL_do_handshake` (attempts to write `33` bytes into the BIO but only is able to write `32` bytes, returns `-1`, `SSL_get_error` returns `SSL_ERROR_WANT_WRITE`)
- OpenSSL attempts to write the `1` remaining byte which wouldn't fit and my custom BIO calls `BIO_set_retry_write(bio)` and return `-1`.
4. Server calls `SSL_set_state(SSL_ST_ACCEPT)`
5. Server calls `SSL_do_handshake` (returns `-1`, `SSL_get_error` returns `SSL_ERROR_WANT_READ`)
- OpenSSL attempts to read from the BIO, but my custom BIO has nothing to read so calls `BIO_set_retry_read(bio)` and returns `-1` 
6. Server reads the `32` pending bytes from the BIO. The BIO now has 32 bytes of free space.
7. Server calls `SSL_do_handshake` (returns `-1`, `SSL_get_error` returns `SSL_ERROR_WANT_READ`)
- OpenSSL tries to read from the BIO. I would expect OpenSSL to try to write the `1` byte which has not been written.

I also have a code reproducer, but the code involves Java & JNI (https://github.com/netty/netty/pull/6201). Let me know if you are interested and I can list the steps required to run the code.

issue.title: OpenSSL ByteBuffer BIO

repository.name: netty
repository.description: Netty project - an event-driven asynchronous network application framework

issue.body:
Motivation:
Currently Netty utilizes BIO_new_bio_pair so we can control all FD lifetime and event notification but delegates to OpenSSL for encryption/decryption. The current implementation sets up a pair of BIO buffers to read/write encrypted/plaintext data. This approach requires copying of data from Java ByteBuffers to native memory BIO buffers, and also requires both BIO buffers to be sufficiently large to hold application data. If direct ByteBuffers are used we can avoid coyping to/from the intermediate BIO buffer and just read/write directly from the direct ByteBuffer memory. We still need an internal buffer because OpenSSL may generate write data as a result of read calls (e.g. handshake, alerts, renegotiation, etc..), but this buffer doesn't have to be be large enough to hold application data.

Modifications:
- Take advantage of the new ByteBuffer based BIO provided by netty-tcnative instead of using BIO_read and BIO_write.

Result:
Less copying and lower memory footprint requirement per TLS connection.

issue.title: Fixes to allow building with OpenSSL 1.1.0e

repository.name: netty-tcnative
repository.description: A fork of Apache Tomcat Native, based on finagle-native

issue.body:
If you try to build 2.0.0.Final with OpenSSL 1.1.0e you get a few errors:
- You can no longer access `SSL_CIPHER->algorithm_mkey` and `SSL_CIPHER->algorithm_auth` they are replaced with `SSL_CIPHER_get_kx_nid` and `SSL_CIPHER_get_auth_nid`. Also Kerberos was removed, so `SSL_TXT_KRB5` was not found
- `X509_STORE_CTX->untrusted` is also not accessible and replaced with `X509_STORE_CTX_get0_untrusted`
- `SSL_CTX_set_tmp_ecdh` changed its behavior. It now sets the supported curves. Which will cause errors like [this](https://github.com/openssl/openssl/issues/2006). Related [Manual](https://wiki.openssl.org/index.php/Manual:SSL_CTX_set1_curves(3)#NOTES) and [OpenSSL issue](https://github.com/openssl/openssl/issues/1437) 
- `SSL_CTX_new(TLSvXX_method());` is deprecated and was replaced with the new `SSL_CTX_new(TLS_method())` [Manual](https://www.openssl.org/docs/man1.1.0/ssl/SSL_CTX_new.html#HISTORY)
This is hacky as `io.netty.handler.ssl.OpenSsl#doesSupportProtocol` also uses `SSL_CTX_new` to test for supported protocols, but for basic support of OpenSSL 1.1.0 it works. 

Furthermore in OpenSSL 1.1.0 the way protocols are enable/disabled changes (SSL_OP_NO_SSLv3,... are deprecated and you should use [this](https://www.openssl.org/docs/man1.1.0/ssl/SSL_CTX_set_max_proto_version.html) instead). However this is a out of scope for this PR.

issue.title: Remove usage of SSL_set_state

repository.name: netty-tcnative
repository.description: A fork of Apache Tomcat Native, based on finagle-native

issue.body:
According to the [OpenSSL changelog](https://www.openssl.org/news/changelog.html), _SSL_set_state() has been removed altogether._ in 1.1.0.

Therefore, compiling netty-tcnative against 1.1.0e results in a compile error.

This is related to https://github.com/netty/netty/issues/6320

```

[INFO] /bin/sh ./libtool  --tag=CC   --mode=compile gcc -DHAVE_CONFIG_H -I. -I./src     -O3 -Werror -fno-omit-frame-pointer -Wunused-variable -DHAVE_OPENSSL -I/Users/snazy/devel/netty/netty-tcnative/openssl-static/target/ssl/include  -I/Users/snazy/devel/netty/netty-tcnative/openssl-static/target/apr/include/apr-1  -D_LARGEFILE64_SOURCE -I/Library/Java/JavaVirtualMachines/jdk1.8.0_121.jdk/Contents/Home/include -I/Library/Java/JavaVirtualMachines/jdk1.8.0_121.jdk/Contents/Home/include/darwin -c -o src/ssl.lo src/ssl.c
[INFO] libtool: compile:  gcc -DHAVE_CONFIG_H -I. -I./src -O3 -Werror -fno-omit-frame-pointer -Wunused-variable -DHAVE_OPENSSL -I/Users/snazy/devel/netty/netty-tcnative/openssl-static/target/ssl/include -I/Users/snazy/devel/netty/netty-tcnative/openssl-static/target/apr/include/apr-1 -D_LARGEFILE64_SOURCE -I/Library/Java/JavaVirtualMachines/jdk1.8.0_121.jdk/Contents/Home/include -I/Library/Java/JavaVirtualMachines/jdk1.8.0_121.jdk/Contents/Home/include/darwin -c src/ssl.c  -fno-common -DPIC -o src/.libs/ssl.o
[INFO] src/ssl.c:1605:5: error: implicit declaration of function 'SSL_set_state' is invalid in C99 [-Werror,-Wimplicit-function-declaration]
[INFO]     SSL_set_state(ssl_, state);
[INFO]     ^
[INFO] src/ssl.c:1605:5: note: did you mean 'SSL_get_state'?
[INFO] /Users/snazy/devel/netty/netty-tcnative/openssl-static/target/ssl/include/openssl/ssl.h:1699:29: note: 'SSL_get_state' declared here
[INFO] __owur OSSL_HANDSHAKE_STATE SSL_get_state(const SSL *ssl);
[INFO]                             ^
[INFO] 1 error generated.
[INFO] make: *** [src/ssl.lo] Error 1
[INFO] rc: 2
```

body:
OpenSSL 1.1.0e cannot be used in netty-tcnative, because SSL_set_state no longer exists in OpenSSL since 1.1.0 (https://github.com/netty/netty-tcnative/issues/263).
Given that OpenSSL 1.1.1 (hopefully) supports TLS 1.3, it seems worth to remove usage of SSL_set_state.

I don't know if this helps, but this is how apache tcnative does the renegotiation (in an older version): https://github.com/apache/tomcat-native/blob/043f95087f712595598901b7c5f915ca5fbf86d5/native/src/sslnetwork.c#L650
In the trunk they removed the `SSL_set_state` call completely: https://github.com/apache/tomcat-native/blob/trunk/native/src/sslnetwork.c#L632

issue.title: java.lang.UnsatisfiedLinkError: io.netty.internal.tcnative.Library.aprMajorVersion()I

repository.name: netty-tcnative
repository.description: A fork of Apache Tomcat Native, based on finagle-native

issue.body:

	at io.netty.internal.tcnative.Library.initialize(Library.java:113) ~[netty-tcnative-2.0.5.Final-linux-x86_64.jar:2.0.5.Final]

body: I honestly don't know enough to determine whether renegotiation is necessary or alternative approaches.

issue.title: OpenSslEngine: Remove renegotiation support

repository.name: netty
repository.description: Netty project - an event-driven asynchronous network application framework

issue.body:
This is the minimum number of changes necessary to remove the calls to `SSL.setState()`, which are causing problems for `netty-tcnative` building on modern linux distributions.

~~I haven't signed the contributor license agreement~~. I have signed the individual contributor license agreement.

Please read the associated ticket (#6320) for some discussion.

---

### Motivation:

`SSL.setState()` has gone from openssl 1.1. Calling it is, and probably always has been, incorrect. Doing renogitation in this manner is potentially insecure. There have been at least two insecure renegotiation vulnerabilities in users of the OpenSSL library.

Renegotiation is not necessary for correct operation of the TLS protocol.

BoringSSL has already eliminated this functionality, and the tests (now deleted) were not running on BoringSSL.

### Modifications:

If the connection setup has completed, always return that negotiation is not supported. Previously this was done only if we were the client.

Remove the tests for this functionality.

### Result:

Fixes #6320.

issue.title: Remove calls to SSL_set_state

repository.name: netty-tcnative
repository.description: A fork of Apache Tomcat Native, based on finagle-native

issue.body:
See https://github.com/netty/netty/issues/6320 for the only user of this function, and the related discussion.

After this change, netty-tcnative will build on Debian sid/unstable, against openssl 1.1.

---

### Motivation:

`SSL_set_state` has gone from openssl 1.1. Calling it is, and probably always has been, incorrect. It has only ever been used to drive an incorrect renegotiation algorithm. Doing renegotiation in this manner is potentially insecure. There have been at least two insecure renegotiation vulnerabilities in users of the OpenSSL library.

Renegotiation is not necessary for correct operation of the TLS protocol.

### Modifications:

Remove the method, and its implementation.

### Result:

Fixes: #263
Requires: https://github.com/netty/netty/issues/6320
